title: Flag of Guinea-Bissau
text:
The <a href="national%20flag">national</a> flag of <a href="Guinea-Bissau">Guinea-Bissau</a> was adopted in 1973 when independence from <a href="Portugal">Portugal</a> was proclaimed.
Design.
Like the former <a href="flag%20of%20Cape%20Verde">flag of Cape Verde</a>, the flag is based on that of the <a href="African%20Party%20for%20the%20Independence%20of%20Guinea%20and%20Cape%20Verde">African Party for the Independence of Guinea and Cape Verde</a> (PAIGC). The party was established in 1956 to peacefully campaign for independence from <a href="Portugal">Portugal</a> during its <a href="Estado%20Novo%20%28Portugal%29">Estado Novo</a> regime, but turned to armed conflict in the 1960s and was one of the belligerents in the 1963–74 <a href="Guinea-Bissau%20War%20of%20Independence">Guinea-Bissau War of Independence</a>. It is still the dominant party in Guinea-Bissau. The PAIGC party flag was derived from <a href="Flag%20of%20Ghana">that of Ghana</a>, which was the first design to use the Pan-African combination of red, yellow, green, and black in 1957.
In the Ghanaian view, the black star stands for the unity of Africa. Red stands for the blood shed during the struggle for independence, yellow stands for the sun, and green represents hope.
The flag features the traditional <a href="Pan-African">Pan-African</a> colors of gold, green, red, and also the <a href="Black%20Star%20of%20Africa">Black Star of Africa</a>. The flag's design is heavily influenced by the <a href="flag%20of%20Ghana">flag of Ghana</a>. The colors have the same meanings: specifically, the red is for the blood of martyrs, green for forests, and gold for mineral wealth.
